instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3330: What is 820-3330? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.BKL_PWM: What is BKL_PWM? BKL_PWM sets the brightness of the screen. The system will send a PWM signal to BKL_PWM pin to set brightness. If this is low, backlight voltage will boost higher than PPBUS_G3H input, but not enough to make the screen light properly..
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
I have a missing backlight and 0v on <SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL>. I am able to get the backlight to come on if I jump <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> to <SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL>. Any ideas to why <SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL> is 0v?

I get 30 volts on the main backlight line without the jumper

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Normal voltage is 39V there.
Do PRAM reset and comment.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL>
threads.message: I tried to do a pram reset and it did not chime. I then replaced the backlight driver. Now my backlight output is down to 12.* . I am guessing my solder job may be bad. It seemed to go perfectly

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL>
threads.message: changed the backlight driver and I am back up to 27.8v. Since the speakers are connected to the board on this model, I should be hearing it chime when resetting the pram(but it did not)? I did hear it chime originally when first looking at the computer before removing the logic board

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Do you get USB activity?
If yes, look at USB mouse light.
If PRAM works, its light should go off/on; use it instead of chime.

BTW, you can force again the backlight, to have control on the screen; or use external monitor, if possible.
I bet it has EFI password and PRAM reset cannot be done in "blind way".

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL>
threads.message: I do get usb light and when resetting the pram it goes off. Is it normal when a logic board with the speakers attached to it, removed from the case, not to chime?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
You must keep pressing the PRAM reset keys until USB mouse light comes on again.
In fact you are using its light instead of chime.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL>
threads.message: I held the keys and reset the pram several times in a row, it flashed multiple times. I was just asking about hearing the chime if the logic board is pulled out as a second quesiton

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL>
threads.message: it is working now. Not sure what happened. it is working with 31.5 volts on backlight out. Is that seem like an issue since it is not 39v?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
I only saw this problem on machines with EFI password.
The last one 3 days ago...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL>
threads.message: what about it working and it is only giving 31.5 volts on the backlight output? Should I be concerned?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
I doubt you can get backlight with less than 34V.
Be sure to measure correctly.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL>
